text: hi everyone oan God Tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new Reverend
Kristen Michael hater album saved this
is a brand new LP from singer songwriter
pianist Reverend Christen Michael hater
formerly known as linga ignota she's
back with a new album under a new name
publicly announcing that she's
abandoning the old one as well as the
material that comes along with it much
of this has to do with the material on
these records being so deeply entwined
with personal trauma very negative
experiences wanting to move past to not
constantly relive these experiences by
performing this stuff again and again
and it seems that new music and a new
name would be the best means of doing
that now with that being said though
musically and aesthetically there's
still a lot of common ground between
what is happening on saved and Kristen's
past couple of Records fans will
instantly recognize her classically
trained vocals her piano playing as well
as some of the experimental prepared
piano touches she's been working into
her stuff too there are also obviously
very deep Ties on this album to religion
worship music and Christianity as well
and I would say this time around Kristen
is getting very high concept with it too
to the point where this album sees her
almost bordering on being in character
cuz saved is not just a straightforward
run of songs from an artist you enjoy
the music here is trying to embody a few
different things one it's a record of
worship music whose cover is graphically
designed to look like uh something off
of a70s televangelists music album and
the music and instrumentation on this LP
is very straightforward it's Bare Bones
it's roughly recorded to tape making it
sound more like a historical artifact
than a studio record it's like this
thing is a folkways recording captured
by an anthropology student who was
staying with some Appalachian
Pentecostal Christian sect that lives in
the mountains and just wanted to
immortalize the weird sorrowful worship
music they make in their Church where
they play with snakes and get up to all
sorts of strange debauchery so in that
sense the appeal of Saved isn't just in
the music or the performances themselves
it's also very much in the vibe that's
being created and what the songs here
are referencing the tone of all this is
set pretty clearly by the opener I'm
getting out while I can not just by
Kristen's howling lead vocals and the
dramatic piano chords but also by the
recording's false stop at one point that
sounds like the uh tape is failing
there's a lot of ambient noise coming
off the room the song is being recorded
in there's even a few points where just
the volume is dropping out the whole
thing ends with this Ultra distorted
recording of what what I think is
Kristen freaking out and speaking in
tongues which I think might be the most
nightmarish thing on any album she's
recorded so far there are also a handful
of shorter Cuts deeper into the record
that are even more lowii and reinforce
this anthropological project energy be
that the group vocal piece there is
power in the blood or the much folkier
precious Lord take my hand and nothing
but the blood of Jesus again with those
titles I think you can tell very much
where this album is going so the element
of reenactment here for the most part is
very immersive however I will say on
occasion I do feel like I'm taken out of
it just a bit because I've heard record
ings before like the ones that Kristen
is trying to mimic here and when I hear
things like some very well tracked group
vocal harmonies it doesn't necessarily
feel as true to the vibe as it could be
I don't know if a Backwater Christian
cult would be able to pull off uh
Kristen's reinterpretation of the track
iduma uh with the technical Precision
that she does not to mention that her
voice is super unique to the point where
her own layered background vocal
uh grab just as much attention as those
that are pushed more toward the
foreground so even if I do enjoy moments
like this in a musical sense I do feel
like they fall a little bit short of
again being fully immersive This Record
does have other core strengths though as
the bulk of it is taken up with these
super straightforward ballads and
spiritual excursions that borrow from a
tradition of hymns and religious folk
music kind of blurring the lines between
what is traditional and what is
Kristen's own original spin on this
stuff like the song all my friends are
going to hell for example which is a
story song of sorts where these
thunderous piano notes uh soundtrack
this word of warning to The Listener to
basically not do the same stuff the
people who are being sung about do as
you know you could end up going to hell
the song is pretty for boing in that
sense but there are other tracks that
take on more of a hopeful and
inspirational tone like may this comfort
and protect you which features these
lovely and Heavenly cord changes that
buzz with whatever metallic material
Kristen has been using to do this
prepared piano stuff brings a sort of
bite and natural Distortion to the
recording that's uh sort of interesting
and the song is gorgeous the performance
is lovely and it's essentially about
having faith and uh taking comfort in
the Lord's love and protection the song
I Will Be With You may sound like one of
the most harrowing moments on the record
on the surface especially with all the
pain and suffering detailed in the
lyrics But ultimately this is a song of
redemption with Kristen about having the
capacity to unburden herself of sin
through her own free will so yeah there
are great songs on this thing that drag
me deep into the theater of what this
record is doing but I think these
recordings being stripped back in the
fashion that they are also serves as a
reminder of how skilled and talented of
a performer Kristen is because on
numerous tracks here just the Simplicity
of her voice and piano playing are
enough to whip at least me up into uh
these entring
o I feel like I'm in a lull or I'm under
a spell on some of these Cuts like on
the poor Wayfaring Stranger and
especially I know his blood can make me
whole when Kristen hits us with those
howling lead vocals and swirling piano
arpeggios This Record sticks The Landing
in an interesting way too with how can I
keep from singing which brings one of
the most tender and solemn performances
on the record all in all it's a pretty
straightforward rendition of the song
but as it progresses it is overtaken a
little bit by again the sound of Kristen
speaking in tongues very quickly very
hurriedly in a fashion that we've heard
at a few different points so far on the
record and as the track goes on it
becomes a form of accompaniment in a way
and makes the whole experience of this
track pretty unnerving especially as the
the speaking in tongues borderline gets
a bit freakish and violent the track is
really performance art in the truth
sense it did take me a few more listens
than I originally anticipated it would
but I did come to love this record not
only for the ways it successfully
captures its concept but Kristen's
creative approach to hymns and American
folk songs as well add on to that some
killer emotional and enthralling
performances and you've got quite the
triple threat of a weird artsy ass album
which for sure is not as heavy or as
Grand in scale as like her past couple
of LPS but is still significant and
impactful in its own way I'm feeling a
light to decent eight on this one TR
